div.head: A BOOK FOR BOTH SEXES.
PRICE, 75 CENTS.
THE PHYSIOLOGY OF MARRIAGE.
div.byline: BY A MARRIED MAN AND DISTINGUISHED PHYSICIAN.
div.p:
This is one of the most remarkable books which has been published in any country. In language simple, decorous, and respectful, and in terms of fatherly kindness, it reveals to the young of both sexes a fund of information hitherto chiefly inaccessible in any reliable form, and for want of which many have been prompted to resort to sources either questionable or of immoral tendency. The work is written by one of our oldest and most experienced medical men, who has devoted a long life to the study of Physiology. The work was examined in manuscript by competent judges, and pronounced to be as unexceptionable as any work which has appeared in the English language. It breathes, moreover, a truly Christian spirit. The following, briefly, are its contents:—
1. The true Relation of the Sexes;—2. Premature Marriage and its consequences;—3. Errors of Education;—4. Errors of Courtship;—5. Individual Transgression and its Penalties;—6. Social Errors and their Punishment;—7. Physical Laws of Marriage;—8. A Fundamental Error;—9. The Laws of Pregnancy;—10. Crime without a name;—11. The Laws of Lactation;—12. A Crime that ought not to be named;—13. Directions to Parents and Guardians;—14. General Directions.

The Newspaper editors use the strongest language in referring to this book. READ WHAT THEY SAY. This book is destined to produce a Physiological Revolution in this country. It will have an immense sale, because it concerns us all, both male and female. The Editor of the Evening Traveller, Boston, uses the following strong language in noticing it:—
"THE PHYSIOLOGY OF MARRIAGE—By an old Physician, 16mo, 259 pages. John P. Jewett & Co. A book that should be read by every man and woman in the land—married or unmarried. It treats of topics of vital interest; but of which not one in a thousand know any thing; who in consequence of their thoughtless ignorance, more than wilful sinfulness, violate the laws of health and even life, bring upon themselves suffering and woe, and upon their offspring enfeebled constitutions, disease, and death. These topics are of a delicate and difficult character, and for this reason good men who were capable of treating them have avoided them. But every reader of the Physiology of Marriage, unless utterly perverted in his tastes and imagination, will admit, on reading these pages, that the "old physician" has dealt with these important topics as an aged father would be likely to do when addressing a beloved child. His instructions and counsels are so plain that none need mistake them, while there is nothing in them to minister to a perverted and prurient taste."
Numerous other notices, equally strong, have been received by the Publishers from all sections of the country.

div.head: DR. HARRIOT K. HUNT.
div.p: We have just published the Autobiography of this EXTRAORDINARY WOMAN, under the title of GLANCES AND GLIMPSES; OR FIFTY YEARS OF SOCIAL, COMPRISING TWENTY YEARS OF PROFESSIONAL LIFE.
In one volume, 12mo. Price, $1.00

This work is meeting with great favor. The editor of the Hartford Republican says of it:—
"A book which should be in the hands of every family in America. Some things in it we do not indorse, but it is a very important and interesting volume. Let Miss Dr. Hunt be read everywhere!"
[From the New York Observer.]
"The life and experiences of a female physician, and the reflections she is constrained to make, render this volume richly worth a study, whatever may be our views of the proprieties of women seeking the medical profession. We think they are in many respects fitted by nature for this work, and we have therefore encouraged them to study the profession. The perusal of this volume, however, will enable one to form some adequate idea of the embarrassments that beset the female practitioner, and while some may be stimulated, others will be deterred."
[From the Daily Bee, Boston.]
"As she is a woman of close observation and trained intellect; a woman of heart as well as mind; who has mingled in the practical, every-day world far more than nine tenths of her sex; who has acted for herself, done the thinking and working of a man as well as woman; who is original, sharp, singular—for these and other reasons her book is a rare, instructive, fascinating, and readable one. How could it be otherwise? She is a live woman; and has written while awake. Few will agree with some of her opinions, for she is ultra. To be ultra, as the world goes, is sometimes to be frightful. Miss Hunt's view of the property question, and some others, have long been the subject of jeer and butt, but with very little wit, and a good deal less sense.—She may be right—we concede she is to a good extent—and merits a respectful hearing. We recommend the book. It is one to read and keep. To take down from the shelf and read again. There is not only thought in it, but food for thought."

div.head: VOICES FROM THE SILENT LAND;
OR Leaves of Consolation for the Afflicted.
div.p: In one elegant 12mo. Plain, $1.00; cloth, full gilt, $1.50; calf extra, $2.50.
"Into the silent land! Ah! who can say that the footsteps of none he once loved on earth have entered the shadow of that pale realm?"

"This is a delightful volume, suited for all: for all have some dear friends who have gone into the 'Silent Land,' and after whom they sometimes cast a longing look into the 'shadows of that pale realm.'

lg.l: 'The air is full of farewells for the dying,
And mournings for the dead.'

div.p: "These 'Voices from the Silent Land,' have been compiled by one while in deep affliction,—her idea being to induce others to make a good and wise use of afflictive dispensations; while, at the same time, she receives soothing consolations to herself.

lg.l: ''Tis sweet, as year by year we lose
Friends out of sight, in faith to muse,
How grows in Paradise our store.'

div.p: "The volume before us is eminently fitted to aid us in such musing; and therefore we heartily commend its perusal to those in affliction."

div.head: The Wesleyan Sacred Harp.
A COLLECTION OF CHOICE TUNES AND HYMNS
FOR PRAYER, CLASS, AND CAMP MEETINGS, CHOIR AND CONGREGATIONAL SINGING.
div.byline: BY Rev. W. MCDONALD, of the Maine Conference, and S. HUBBARD, Esq., Author of Several Musical Works.
div.p: Price, 50 cents single; $4.80 per dozen.
This work is destined to become a very popular music book for social meetings with the Methodist denomination.

Rev. W. F. Farrington, Pastor of the Pine St. Methodist Church, Portland, Maine, a man of fine musical taste, writes thus to the Editor of Zion's Herald, Boston:—
"THE WESLEYAN SACRED HARP. A Collection of Choice Tunes and Hymns for Social and Congregational Singing. By Rev. M. MCDONALD and S. HUBBARD, Esq.
"BRO. WISE:—I wonder that no more has been said publicly in favor of this excellent work! It must be that it has not been examined by a practical test, generally, or that it is thought to possess sufficient merit in itself to recommend it wherever it is known. The selection, composition, and arrangement of the music, and hymns, the latter principally from our standard book, evince a taste and skill, which ought to give it an extensive circulation. It is just the book for our family circles, and social religious meetings. Having the hymn and music before us, on the same page, it will help to correct the time and tune of many who join in this delightful portion of religious worship, and prevent those grotesque and grating sounds which often annihilate melody, and sometimes the devotional feelings even, of those whose ears and voices are scientifically cultivated. Cannot the compiler add in another edition some fifteen or twenty carefully selected tunes and hymns, suitable to be used in our public congregations, where congregational singing has been adopted? And we fondly hope that this method of singing will speedily obtain throughout our New England churches. It is the most conducive to spirituality and union of any mode yet adopted. Success to the 'Harp,' and let every Methodist vestry, especially, be generally supplied with it.
"W. F. FARRINGTON.
"Portland, Nov. 6, 1855."

div.head: Great Work on Spiritualism.
MODERN MYSTERIES EXPLAINED AND EXPOSED
div.p: Complete in one volume. 12mo. Price, $1.00.

From the able Editor of the Cambridge Chronicle:—
"The time has come when the phenomena of Spiritualism must be met and examined. It will not do to deny the facts, and sneer at those who relate them. There is around us a mysterious power, which has been, or can be called into exercise, but which has not been satisfactorily accounted for. The reality of these manifestations in some undoubted cases, has given rise to innumerable shams by which the credulous have been deceived, and the cautious disgusted. By ascribing the wonderful things which have been seen, heard, and felt to the agency of departed spirits, the beholders of these strange doings have disgusted many reasonable men and driven them to deny, not only the cause, but the reality of the facts. The absurdity of attributing to such men as Lord Byron and Shakspeare the commonplace remarks which have been published in revelations from their spirits is enough to throw discredit on the theory which claims for the manifestations a spiritual origin.
"President Mahan gives by far the most satisfactory, reasonable, and philosophical explanation of what is called Spiritualism that we have yet seen. He has devoted much time and earnest thought to the examination of the subject, and we have in this volume the result of his investigations. He does not deny the reality of the cases reported, but takes them up, examines, and explains them by his theory."

Lieut. Gov. Brown of Massachusetts, speaks thus of the work:—
"The book is the ablest and most satisfactory one on this subject that has yet appeared, and should be read by all who wish to inform themselves in regard to these mysterious phenomena."
